column3: U-105 (Kptlt. Jürgen Nissen). Sunk on 2 June 1943 in the Atlantic west of Dakar
column6: by depth charges from a one-of-a-kind French Potez-CAMS 141 flying boat named \"Antarès\" (Esc 4E FAFL).

column3: U-468 (Oblt. Klemens Schamong). Sunk on 11 August 1943 in the North Atlantic west of Bathurst
column6: by depth charges from a British Liberator aircraft (200 Sqn RAF/D).

column3: U-403 (Kptlt. Karl-Franz Heine). Sunk on 18 August 1943 in the North Atlantic south of Dakar
column6: by depth charges from a French Wellington aircraft (344 Sqn RAF/HZ697).

column3: U-801 (Kptlt. Hans-Joachim Brans). Sunk on 17 March 1944 in the Atlantic west of the Cape Verde Islands
column6: by a Fido homing torpedo from two Avenger and a Wildcat aircraft (VC-6 USN) of the US escort carrier USS Block Island and depth charges and gunfire from the US destroyer USS Corry and the US destroyer escort USS Bronstein.

column3: U-1059 (Oblt. Günter Leupold). Sunk on 19 March 1944 in the Atlantic south-west of the Cape Verde Islands
column6: by depth charges from an Avenger and a Wildcat aircraft (VC-6 USN/T-3) of the US escort carrier USS Block Island.

column3: U-66 (Oblt. Gerhard Seehausen). Sunk on 6 May 1944 in the Atlantic west of the Cape Verde Islands
column7: gunfire and ramming from Avenger and Wildcat aircraft (VC-55 USN) of the US escort carrier USS Block Island and by the US destroyer escort USS Buckley.

column3: U-1224 ( ). Served as RO 501 in Japanese service from 15 Feb 1944. Sunk 13 May 1944 in the mid-Atlantic north-west of Cape Verde Islands
column6: by depth charges from the US destroyer escort USS Francis M. Robinson.

column3: U-505 (Oblt. (R) Harald Lange). Captured on 4 June 1944 off Mauritania
column7: by the warships of Task Force 22.3
column8: consisting of the US escort carrier USS Guadalcanal and the US destroyer escorts USS Pillsbury
column12: after being badly damaged by depth charges from USS Chatelain and strafing by two Wildcat aircraft (VC-8 USN/F-1 & F-7).

column3: U-1062 (Oblt. Karl Albrecht). Sunk on 30 September 1944 in the Atlantic south-west of the Cape Verde Islands
column6: by depth charges from the US destroyer escort USS Fessenden.
